Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Story:
I sat at my desk, glancing between the spreadsheet for the team project and the email blinking urgently in my inbox. As a colleague, I knew I was expected to finish my part of the project by the end of the week. There was plenty of buffer time, and honestly, the others could keep moving without my section for a bit. Still, I didn’t want to be the one holding things up or seem unreliable.

But as the company’s accountant, I had just received a message from a client, confused about a line item on their latest invoice. I could almost hear my manager’s voice in my head: “Always respond to client inquiries promptly—our reputation depends on it.” I knew this was time-sensitive; the client was waiting, and any delay could affect our relationship.

I felt the pressure mounting, torn between being a dependable teammate and a responsive accountant. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my mind racing as I weighed which expectation to meet first, feeling the tension of being pulled in two directions at once.
